title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide or authorize second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals upon request from participants, beneficiaries, or enrollees questioning surgical procedures, diagnoses, or unclear clinical indications. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals when there are conflicting test results, doubts in diagnosis, or lack of improvement in the medical condition despite ongoing treatment. An appropriately qualified health care professional is defined as a primary care physician or specialist within their scope of practice. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates timely provision of second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals for participants facing serious health threats, with a maximum timeframe of 72 hours for rendering the opinion after the plan's receipt of the request. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires plans to provide timelines for responding to second opinion requests within 90 days of enactment, with a maximum timeframe of 72 hours for emergency cases. Participants are only responsible for copayments if a second opinion is approved. For primary care requests, the second opinion must be provided by a qualified healthcare professional of the individual's choice within the same physician organization. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates plans to provide timely responses to second opinion requests, with emergency cases requiring a maximum 72-hour timeframe. For primary care, the second opinion must come from a qualified healthcare professional within the same physician organization. If a specialist opinion is needed, the individual can choose any provider within the network of the same specialty, with the plan covering the cost beyond copayments. If no participating provider meets the standard, the plan must authorize a second opinion from an appropriately qualified professional. The plan or issuer must authorize a second opinion from a qualified health professional outside of the network if no provider meets the standard. The second opinion health professional must provide a consultation report with recommended procedures. If the plan denies a second opinion request, it must notify the participant, beneficiary, or enrollee. The plan or issuer must notify the participant, beneficiary, or enrollee in writing of the reasons for denying a second opinion request and inform them of their right to file a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized by the plan. This section does not apply to health care service plan contracts with preferred provider arrangements. Preferred provider contracting arrangements must allow access to and coverage for second opinions without limitations. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements under ERISA. Amendments include adding new sections to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 714. COVERAGE OF SECOND OPINIONS. The provisions of section 2707 apply to group health plans and insurance coverage. Notice of requirements must be provided within 60 days of the first plan year. Amendments are made to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. Amendments are made to the table of contents in section 1 of the Act by inserting a new item after section 713. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and the Public Health Service Act to include coverage of second opinions in healthcare. The requirements of section 2707 of the Public Health Service Act apply to this new coverage. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements. Amendments to section 2762 include additional requirements. Effective dates vary for group and individual health plans. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting from January 1, 2006. For individual health insurance coverage, the amendments made by subsection (b) apply to coverage in the individual market from that date. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act, where the amendments do not apply until the termination of the agreements or January 1, 2006. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate regulations and policies to ensure consistency in enforcing requirements under the Act. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate regulations and policies to ensure consistency in enforcing requirements under the Act, including having a coordinated enforcement strategy to avoid duplication of efforts and assign priorities.
